newsitem.title: UK: LCE cocoa ends with small losses as rally falters.
newsitem.headline: LCE cocoa ends with small losses as rally falters.

text.p: London cocoa futures ended with small losses in slow dealings as early short-covering and industry price-fixing fizzled out on sterling's strength in currency trading.
"It ran out of steam. It ran out of buying. I think the trouble is because sterling has gone up against the European rates," said a trader.

The London cocoa contract is priced in sterling. Sterling climbed on Thursday against German mark and hit 10-month high versus the dollar after upbeat Confederation of British Industry retail survey, buoyed by unchanged UK interest rates.
By the finish, the benchmark December cocoa was six stg off at 969 stg a tonne. It had climbed to the day's high of 980.
Traders said the downside was well supported by lack of keen origin selling.
"I don't see much in the way of origin cocoa. At these levels, we don't expect them to sell," said a trader.
Overall volume reached a modest 4,558 lots. Switches involving forward positions were active with March 1997/March 1998 seen trading at 70 stg.
On the charts, analysts pegged key hurdle at 1,000 stg basis December.
On the downside, the recent six-month low of 955 stg should serve as nearby support, followed by a four stg March chart gap under 950 stg and the March low of 935.
